Award.AwardTitle: Conference: The Multiple Dimensions of Biodiversity Science; Sao Paulo, Brazil, June 26-30, 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding and predicting spatial patterns of biodiversity and turnover in space and time is central to understanding the interplay between ecology and evolution. Despite the appeal of broadly integrative research programs, advances in biodiversity science have been constrained by the isolation of these fields within biology, as well as between biology and related fields such as geology and climate science. This symposium seeks to identify and broadcast new ways to overcome the challenge of effectively uniting the fields of earth sciences, evolution and ecology through research, teaching, and outreach. Participants will include graduate students, postdocs, and principle investigators associated with the NSF Dimensions of Biodiversity program from the US, and from partner funding agencies in Brazil and China. This meeting will provide a unique opportunity to disseminate new and promising integrative approaches to biodiversity studies, and to brainstorm and discuss the best strategies to educate and train the next generation of integrative scientists. This research is of high priority for developing viable approaches to conservation and sustainability in the neotropics that can be applied in diverse geographic regions.

This funding will support the participation of US-based graduate students and postdocs from diverse backgrounds who are conducting cutting-edge research in integrative approaches to biodiversity studies, as well as four undergraduate minority students involved with or interested in similar topics. All student awardees will attend the symposium and be invited to actively participate in the symposium discussions and a joint publication emerging from it. Student posters will be advertised to the symposium audience to maximize their attendance. The poster session will use the scientific networks of our speakers to foster new connections and collaborations between attendees from South America and those from other continents, thereby fostering new scientific links across countries. Local outreach efforts in Brazil will feature new integrative studies that either focus on or encompass tropical biotas, or that develop novel frameworks that can be readily applied to these regions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We gathered a team of ecologists, evolutionary biologists, and environmental scientists associated with the Dimensions of Biodiversity program, jointly funded by NSF and its international partner institutions, to present and discuss how cross-disciplinary collaborations are advancing what we know about the generation, maintenance, and loss of biodiversity. For this, we hosted a Dimensions of Biodiversity Symposium during an international meeting attended by ca. 1000 scientists from throughout the Americas: the 2015 joint annual meeting of the Society for the Study of Evolution (SSE), the Society of Systematic Biologists (SSB), and the American Society of Naturalists (ASN), in Guarujá, São Paulo, Brazil. Capitalizing on their experiences, we used that opportunity not only to showcase new and promising integrative approaches to biodiversity studies, but also to brainstorm and discuss the very best strategies to educate and train the next generation of integrative scientists and to face the challenges experienced by those conducting integrative studies of biodiversity. Thirty scientific presentations were supported by this project during that event. Those presentations were given by faculty, postdocs, and students associated with NSF’s Dimensions of Biodiversity program.

One of the most important obstacles to biodiversity research, as identified during the symposium, related to data integration and data management. Our yet limited ability to connect and explore linked biodiversity information from multiple dimensions and scales hinders the advancement of biodiversity theory and our understanding of the general processes that may underscore biodiversity generation, maintenance, and erosion. To address this gap, a subset of the symposium participants - including one Ph.D. student, two faculty members, and one postdoc – worked together on a Data Integration Workshop proposal and led a 2-day discussion at the University of Florida in 2017, with the participation of additional research groups involved with the Dimensions of Biodiversity program. This event discussed best practices and a new framework to promote integration of biodiversity data from the many areas and natural systems funded by NSF. As a result of this discussion, the group is now writing a perspective article and jointly submitted two follow-up grant proposals: one to coordinate research across our biodiversity studies, and one to integrate data generated by current Dimensions of Biodiversity groups.

To maximize the reach of our events, this project also offered competitive student travel grants to the 2015 symposium, supporting the participation of 20 US-based graduate students, postdocs and undergraduates conducting cutting-edge research in integrative approaches to biodiversity studies. In 2017, our Data Integration Workshop supported the participation of seven graduate students and postdocs in the University of Florida gathering. Finally, in 2018, the project supported two female Latino graduate students and one female postdoc as they presented their Dimensions work at the Climate Change Biogeography meeting of the International Biogeography Society in Portugal. The 2015 Symposium, as well as the 2017 Data Integration Workshop and the 2018 presentations provided unique networking opportunities to awardees and the speakers. As a result of those interactions, several have identified new professional mentors amongst the more senior participants and symposium speakers, and at least five are collaborating in follow-up grants.
